6.22.text: Just around the corner from St Ethelreda's church

9.58.text: the oldest Catholic church in London

11.50.text: down this funny little alley way

13.06.text: is one of my favourite pubs, Ye Olde Mitre

15.84.text: the whole area around here is called Hatton Garden

17.88.text: and Sir Christopher Hatton was one of Queen Elizabeth the first's favourites

21.06.text: roughly translated as "her bit on the side"

25.90.text: They were a lot shorter in those days

28.30.text: A "mitre" is a bishop's hat, and back in the 14th century, just around the corner there was a palace

33.96.text: which became the town residence of the bishop of Ely, which is in Cambridgeshire

38.18.text: and this would have been the servants' quarters for the palace

46.68.text: There's a tree downstairs that existed in the time of Queen Elizabeth the first

51.96.text: You have to go out of that door and into the other part of the pub

54.60.text: if you go inside that door there in this corner you'll see it

57.46.text: It's supporting this part of the building right now

58.86.text: when they rebuilt the building they had to build it around that because it's actually a supporting beam

64.04.text: Queen Elizabeth danced the maypole around it

66.40.text: Now because she was unmarried she was called the virgin queen famously but she still had loads of lovers

70.78.text: and when she confiscated a load of grounds from the Bishop of Ely's palace around the corner

75.84.text: in order to give it to her lover, Christopher Hatton for when he came to London for a bit of "how's your father"

81.04.text: The bishop got upset and he refused

84.56.text: Proud prelate, I understand you are backward in complying

87.40.text: I would have you understand that I who made you what you are can unmake you.

91.04.text: if you do not faithfully fulfil your engagement by God I will immediately unfrock you!

96.62.text: So that tree marks the boundary between the Bishop of Ely's grounds and Christopher Hatton's grounds

104.22.text: In Richard II by Shakespeare this is where John of Gaunt says his famous speech

112.02.text: This sceptered isle, this precious stone set in a silver sea

125.10.text: You can get a bit drunk doing these films
